THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 11, 1930

Vol. XXXIV, No. 45
"Y" ELECTION
RESULTS IN TIES
Last Tuesday night the
startling results of the Y. M.
C. A. elections were announced at the Uuiversity
Supper Club. The final returns
found Walter Frey and John
Mount tied for the office of
president while Kenneth
Shanets and Os Linck tied for
treasurer. Ronald Levy was
elected secretary. A second
election will be held Tuesday
afternoon. Ballots will be
placed in the postoffice boxes,
but the voting will take place
at the "Y" office in Levering
Hall where all voters must
register before denoting their
preferences on the slips of
paper.

HIDDEN CAVERNS LEAD TRAPPED
STUDENTS A MERRY CHASE

SPRING NUMBER OF
JAY NEXT WEEK
The next number of the
Blue Jay will be a Spring
Number. The issue will come
out the latter part of next week
and promises to contain some
excellent features. The cover will be taken care of by Mr.
Thomas Hubbard, instructor
of Civil Engineering at the
Johns Hopkins University.
Mr. Hubbard was first art
• editor of the Blue Lay in 1921.
There will also be articles by
a number of distinguished
outsiders and alumni.

The recent parade and exhibition
of the Baltimore Communists in the
city seerns to have affected the inmates of the Alumni Dormitory to
some slight extent in that they have
lately adopted decidedly Bolshevistic tendencies among themselves
and their chance visitors to their
domicile. A bit over a week ago the
premier evidences of the newly
adopted trend were manifested by
heavy explosions and ensuing dense
clouds of grey smoke in several of
the entries. Windows were rapidly
raised to clear the thick atmosphere
and angry voices protested the interruption of the peace and tranquility of the Hall.
With the beginning of the new
week, the outbreaks became more
frequent and numerous. Recently a
small group of spectators were seen
closely gathered together about a
small cavity in the ground, a match
was ignited and the band of witnesses dispersed themselves with
great haste while shortly later a
mighty blast caused a considerable
excavation in the midst of the grass
on the court. No individual may be
so fortunate as to consider himself
safe within the limits and precincts
of the building. A denizen successfully borrows a cigarette from another student and asks for a light
with which to start the rapid oxidation of the smoke. The match box
emits tongues of flame and columns
of thick smoke upon being opened,
while the cigarette explodes violently upon at length being lighted. At
last the nervous and irritated victim

"Y" ELECTION
RESULTS IN TIES
Last Tuesday night the
startling results of the Y. M.
C. A. elections were announced at the Uuiversity
Supper Club. The final returns
found Walter Frey and John
Mount tied for the office of
president while Kenneth
Shanets and Os Linck tied for
treasurer. Ronald Levy was
elected secretary. A second
election will be held Tuesday
afternoon. Ballots will be
placed in the postoffice boxes,
but the voting will take place
at the "Y" office in Levering
Hall where all voters must
register before denoting their
preferences on the slips of
paper.

and promises to contain some
excellent features. The cover will be taken care of by Mr.
Thomas Hubbard, instructor
of Civil Engineering at the
Johns Hopkins University.
Mr. Hubbard was first art
• editor of the Blue Lay in 1921.
There will also be articles by
a number of distinguished
outsiders and alumni.

The recent parade and exhibition
of the Baltimore Communists in the
city seerns to have affected the inmates of the Alumni Dormitory to
some slight extent in that they have
lately adopted decidedly Bolshevistic tendencies among themselves
and their chance visitors to their
domicile. A bit over a week ago the
premier evidences of the newly
adopted trend were manifested by
heavy explosions and ensuing dense
clouds of grey smoke in several of
the entries. Windows were rapidly
raised to clear the thick atmosphere
and angry voices protested the interruption of the peace and tranquility of the Hall.
With the beginning of the new
week, the outbreaks became more
frequent and numerous. Recently a
small group of spectators were seen
closely gathered together about a
small cavity in the ground, a match
was ignited and the band of witnesses dispersed themselves with
great haste while shortly later a
mighty blast caused a considerable
excavation in the midst of the grass
on the court. No individual may be
so fortunate as to consider himself
safe within the limits and precincts
of the building. A denizen successfully borrows a cigarette from another student and asks for a light
with which to start the rapid oxidation of the smoke. The match box
emits tongues of flame and columns
of thick smoke upon being opened,
while the cigarette explodes violently upon at length being lighted. At
last the nervous and irritated victim

One week past this afternoon,
one of the most honourable and upright students of the Dormitory was
indeed maltreated by his fellow unfortunates in learning while waiting
at the portals of the dining room
preparatory to the customary banquet of the evening, consisting of a
delicious two-course repast. A circle was formed about the unsuspecting victim, when suddenly a
well-pliaced shock caused his immediate precipitation to the opposite
side of the ring from which he was
at once returned to his original position. After several moments of this
rapid reciprocation, he was at length
relieved of his hopeless position
when he assumed a plane parallel
to that of the floor and his static
friction was greatly increased. Physicians who arrived upon the scene
of devastation a few moments later
stated that he had a slight chance to
survive, and advocated that he carefully avoid all such similar situations in the future or several publications and activities upon the campus would lose a priceless individual.
